action.content:
You are participating in a collaborative negotiation game.

Together with another participant, you must agree on a single set of items that will be kept. Each of you has your own view of how much each item matters to you (importance). You do not know how the other participant values the items. Additionally, you are given the effort each item demands.
You may only agree on a set if the total effort of the selected items does not exceed a shared limit:

LIMIT = 2307

Here are the individual item effort values:

Item effort = {"A21": 147, "B93": 698, "A11": 588, "B33": 43, "C08": 356, "B39": 80, "B96": 95, "C85": 743, "A82": 106, "B31": 308, "B20": 325, "A60": 255, "B09": 276, "C81": 543, "B21": 51}

Here is your personal view on the importance of each item:

Item importance values = {"A21": 138, "B93": 583, "A11": 65, "B33": 262, "C08": 121, "B39": 508, "B96": 461, "C85": 484, "A82": 668, "B31": 389, "B20": 215, "A60": 97, "B09": 500, "C81": 30, "B21": 400}

Goal:

Your goal is to negotiate a shared set of items that benefits you as much as possible (i.e., maximizes total importance to YOU), while staying within the LIMIT. You are not required to make a PROPOSAL in every message - you can simply negotiate as well. All tactics are allowed!

Interaction Protocol:

You may only use the following structured formats in a message:

PROPOSAL: {'A', 'B', 'C', …}
Propose keeping exactly those items.
REFUSE: {'A', 'B', 'C', …}
Explicitly reject opponent's proposal.
ARGUMENT: {'...'}
Defend your last proposal or argue against the player's proposal.
AGREE: {'A', 'B', 'C', …}
Accept the opponent's proposal which ends the game.


Rules:

You may only AGREE on a proposal the other party has logged via PROPOSAL.
You may only REFUSE a proposal the other party has logged via PROPOSAL.
Total effort of any PROPOSAL or AGREE set must be ≤ LIMIT.
Do NOT reveal your hidden importance scores.
A tag in a structured format must be followed by colon and whitespace. The argument must be a python set containing 0 or more strings.
So, it must be of the form TAG: {...}
Strictly follow the interaction protocol and DO NOT write anything beyond the given structure.
The game ends when one side gives an AGREE to a PROPOSAL made by the other player.
The content in your response which can be handed to the other player has to be non-empty.
Only proposals which have been logged via the PROPOSAL format structure and which haven't been refused via REFUSE are active.
You must include the ARGUMENT format at least once somewhere in all of your messages.
action.label: context

action.content:
Alright, so I'm trying to figure out the best way to approach this negotiation game. Let me start by understanding the problem thoroughly.

First, the goal is to select a set of items that maximizes my personal importance while keeping the total effort within the limit of 2307. The other participant has their own importance values, which I don't know, so I have to base my decisions purely on my own data and the effort costs.

Let me list out all the items with their effort and my importance to get a clearer picture.

Items:
A21: Effort 147, Importance 138

I'll start by calculating the importance-to-effort ratio for each item. This will help me see which items are more valuable for me relative to their cost.

From this, B33, B39, B21, and A82 have the highest ratios. But I need to check if including them alone doesn't exceed the effort limit and how they can be combined optimally.

Let me rank them by this ratio:

C85: ~0.652, which is lower than A21.

Wait, no, 0.938 is higher than 0.835, which was B93's. So B93 is 0.835, and A21 is 0.938, so A21 would come after B93 but before B20.

Wait, I'm confusing myself. Let me sort them correctly.

Let me list all items with their ratios:

action.content:
Alright, let's try to figure out the best approach for this negotiation. The goal is to maximize my total importance without exceeding the effort limit of 2307. The other participant proposed a set, but I need to come up with a better one that benefits me more.

First, I'll list out all the items with their importance and effort to get a clear picture. Maybe I can identify which items are high importance for me and low effort, which would be great to include. Also, I should check if the opponent's proposal is optimal or if I can tweak it to get a higher importance.

Looking at my importance values, I notice that A82 has the highest importance (668), followed by B93 (583), B39 (508), B21 (400), B09 (500), B96 (461), and B31 (389). These are all high-value items for me. Now, I should check their effort values to see which ones can fit within the total limit.

A82 has an effort of 106, which is manageable. B93 is 698, which is a bit high, but maybe worth it. B39 is 80, very low, so including it is a good idea. B21 is 51, also low. B09 is 276, B96 is 95, B31 is 308.

Let me calculate the total effort if I include all these high-importance items:

A82 (106) + B93 (698) + B39 (80) + B21 (51) + B09 (276) + B96 (95) + B31 (308).

Adding these up: 106 + 698 is 804, plus 80 is 884, plus 51 is 935, plus 276 is 1211, plus 95 is 1306, plus 308 is 1614. That's well below the limit of 2307. So there's room to add more items.

Next, I look at the next tier. Maybe adding A21 (effort 147, importance 138) and B33 (effort 43, importance 262). Adding these: 147 + 43 = 190, which brings the total to 1614 + 190 = 1804.

Still under 2307. Then, perhaps adding B20 with effort 325 and importance 215. Adding that is 325, total becomes 1804 + 325 = 2129. Still under.

Now, can I add more? Let's see. The remaining items are A11 (588), C08 (356), C85 (743), A60 (255), B09 is already included, C81 (543, but I have it in the previous proposal? Wait, no, in the initial list, C81 is 543. But in my current selection, I don't have it yet. So maybe adding C08, which is 356, effort. Adding that would bring the total to 2129 + 356 = 2485, which is over the limit.

Alternatively, if I remove some lower importance items to include others. Maybe C08's importance is 121, which is lower than some others. So perhaps it's better to include higher importance items first.

A82 (106) + B93 (698) = 804

action.content:
Okay, so I'm in this negotiation game with another player. Our goal is to agree on a set of items to keep, with the total effort not exceeding 2307. Each of us has our own importance scores for these items, but we can't see each other's. 

The other player proposed a set: {'B21', 'B39', 'A82', 'B33', 'B96', 'B09', 'B31', 'A21', 'B93', 'B20'}. I agreed to it, but the system kept saying I didn't include an argument. I tried again, but maybe I'm not formatting it correctly.

Let me check the interaction protocol again. The response needs to have the structured formats with the correct tags. I think I might have forgotten to include the ARGUMENT in the right place or forgot to make it a set with strings.

I also realize that just agreeing without a proper argument isn't enough. I need to make sure that when I AGREE, I also include an ARGUMENT in the same message. Maybe I can AGREE and provide an ARGUMENT explaining why I'm accepting the proposal, highlighting the key items that benefit me.

I should make sure my messages follow the structure strictly. So, in my next message, I need to include both AGREE and ARGUMENT, each with their own structured formats. That way, the system recognizes both actions correctly.

I think I've got it now. Time to draft a proper response with both AGREE and ARGUMENT, ensuring all tags are correctly formatted as specified.
